discussion.content:
Get-AzureADDirectorySettingTemplate and Get-AzureADGroup:

$GroupName = "<GroupName>"
Connect-AzureAD
$template = Get-AzureADDirectorySettingTemplate | ? {$_.displayname -eq "group.unified.guest"}
$settingsCopy = $template.CreateDirectorySetting()
$settingsCopy["AllowToAddGuests"]=$False
$groupID= (Get-AzureADGroup -SearchString $GroupName).ObjectId
New-AzureADObjectSetting -TargetType Groups -TargetObjectId $groupID -DirectorySetting $settingsCopy

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/solutions/per-group-guest-access?view=o365-worldwide
Second answer is wrong, should be Get-AzureADGroups (as shown below and confirmed in link)
The answer should be, this is an absurd question, which I'm looking up on the internet if I ever need to do it, and will never remember a month after I've passed. But thx for the answer Carlos.
The answer should be "Get-AzureADDirectorySettingTemplate" and "Get-AzureADGroup"

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that contains a Microsoft Teams team named Confidential.

You need to ensure that guest users cannot be added to the Confidential team.

How should you complete the PowerShell script? To answer, drag the appropriate values to the correct targets. Each value may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
B and C
On exam 31/03/2023
On exam 30-March-2023

Selected Answer: BC
B and C: 

SRV _sipfederationtls._tcp.<sipdomain>
_sipfederationtls._tcp.contoso.com External Access Edge FQDN
Access1.contoso.com Used for Federation and public IM connectivity

Selected Answer: BC
B and C are the correct answers. 

Correct me if I'm wrong. I don't have exact details but this is the closest answers to this question.

comments.content: but who said anything about internal users? The question states for customers, so it will need federation record. I think the answer is correct (External access on Teams AC and _sipfederationtls SRV record)

discussion.content:
B. From the Microsoft Teams admin center, turn on external access.
D. Add a _sipinternaltls SRV record to the contoso.com DNS domain.

You need to turn on external access in the Microsoft Teams admin center to allow users to communicate with Skype consumers. You also need to add a _sipinternaltls SRV record to the contoso.com DNS domain to allow Skype consumers to find and communicate with users on your organization's domain.
This will allow your teams users to search for customers that use Skype (Consumer) and start a Skype chat with them.
Note: A & C are incorrect as they are used for federation with other organizations and E is not related to this scenario.

DNS records for Skype for business 

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/skypeforbusiness/plan-your-deployment/network-requirements/dns

choices.A: From the Microsoft Teams admin center, turn on guest access.
choices.D: Add a _sipinternaltls SRV record to the contoso.com DNS domain.
choices.C: Add a _sipfederationtls SRV record to the contoso.com DNS domain.
choices.B: From the Microsoft Teams admin center, turn on external access.
choices.E: From the Azure portal, configure Azure AD B2C.

questions.question_text:
Your company uses Microsoft Teams.

You are assigned the Groups Administrator role.

You discover that you cannot create an expiration policy in Microsoft 365.

You need to create the expiration policy. The solution must use the principle of least privilege.

What should you do first?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Configuring and using the expiration policy for Microsoft 365 groups requires you to possess but not necessarily assign Microsoft Entra ID P1 or P2 licenses for the members of all groups to which the expiration policy is applied. For more information, see Getting started with Microsoft Entra ID P1 or P2.
 
Groups Administrator ---- Members of this role can create/manage groups, create/manage groups settings like naming and expiration policies, and view groups activity and audit reports.(as of March4,2025)
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/solutions/microsoft-365-groups-expiration-policy?view=o365-worldwide#who-can-configure-and-use-the-microsoft-365-groups-expiration-policy

Groups Administrator role is already assigned to user so the only option left is (A) Upgrade the Azure AD liscense.

***Microsoft recommends that you use roles with the fewest permissions. This helps improve security for your organization. Global Administrator is a highly privileged role that should be limited to emergency scenarios when you can't use an existing role.***

Selected Answer: A
Group administrator can already create expiration policies

Selected Answer: A
Groups Administrator role can manage/create the expiration policy.
So the answer is: A. Upgrade the Azure AD license.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/solutions/microsoft-365-groups-expiration-policy?view=o365-worldwide

Selected Answer: A
See link by Nico 282 : You are assigned group administrator, so you are allowed to set retentions. The other requirement is an AzureAD license.

Selected Answer: A
https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/microsoft-365-groups/introducing-the-groups-admin-role/m-p/978995

Selected Answer: C
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/solutions/microsoft-365-groups-expiration-policy?view=o365-worldwide#who-can-configure-and-use-the-microsoft-365-groups-expiration-policy

Selected Answer: C

Who can configure and use the Microsoft 365 groups expiration policy?
Office 365 global admin (in Azure, the Company administrator), User administrator

a group administrator is able to configure a M365 group expiration policy but the feature is bundled in an Azure AD premium license. so the first thing to check if the group administrator is unable to configure M365 expiration is the license if it is premium so the answer should be A

Selected Answer: A
Configuring and using the expiration policy for Microsoft 365 groups requires you to possess but not necessarily assign Azure AD Premium licenses for the members of all groups to which the expiration policy is applied.
Role: Global administrator, Group administrator, or User administrator. Remenber, the solution must use the principle of least privilege.
 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/enterprise-users/groups-lifecycle

Selected Answer: C
When you sign up for Microsoft 365 Business, you automatically become a global admin. So you have to assume in this scenario there was already a global admin in place.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/add-users/assign-admin-roles?view=o365-worldwide

discussion.content:

Office 365 global admin (in Azure, the Company administrator), User administrator: Create, read, update, or delete the Microsoft 365 groups expiration policy settings.

We indeed require Azure AD premium but However the Group Expiration Policy can only be enabled by a Global or User Administrator for your tenant. Let's assume they're just lack of administration authority
On test 28.04.2023 (I'm not a bot you can trust me :D) - Reveal solution then check discussion and go for the high upvoted answers in discussion :)

comments.content:
Can you cite your source?

MS document states (As of today) that only: "Office 365 global admin (in Azure, the Company administrator), User administrator" can configure this, no mention of the role the question states: "Group Administrator"

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/solutions/microsoft-365-groups-expiration-policy?view=o365-worldwide#who-can-configure-and-use-the-microsoft-365-groups-expiration-policy

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is the right answer: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/solutions/microsoft-365-groups-expiration-policy?view=o365-worldwide#who-can-configure-and-use-the-microsoft-365-groups-expiration-policy

Answer : A is correct

Note: Configuring and using the expiration policy for Microsoft 365 groups requires you to possess but not necessarily assign Azure AD Premium licenses for the members of all groups to which the expiration policy is applied.

Roles: Global administrator, Group administrator, or User administrator
Permissions: Can create, read, update, or delete the Microsoft 365 groups expiration policy settings
Can renew any Microsoft 365 group

Selected Answer: C
C. Request the Global Administrator role.

In order to create an expiration policy in Microsoft 365, you need to have the Global Administrator role. The Global Administrator is the only role that has the permissions to create an expiration policy. Therefore, the first step you should take is to request the Global Administrator role from your organization's IT department.
A and D are not related to this scenario, and B is incorrect as modifying the Global Administrator role doesn't help in creating an expiration policy.

comments.content: I think as was pointed out earlier in this thread (earlier meaning I've already scrolled past it), the statement of "least privilege" is what makes A the correct answer IN THIS CASE. Because a Group Admin is going to have less privilege than a Global Admin, so everything else being equal, the Azure AD premium license is the better choice for this question.

Thanks for citing your source!

Seems that Microsoft has 2 seemingly contradicting documents on the same topic

This makes no mention of the Group Administrator role being capable of setting expiration for groups:

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/solutions/microsoft-365-groups-expiration-policy?view=o365-worldwide#who-can-configure-and-use-the-microsoft-365-groups-expiration-policy

This other one *does* indicate that Group Administrator can do it

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/enterprise-users/groups-lifecycle#roles-and-permissions

Further confirmed by this:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/add-users/about-admin-roles?view=o365-worldwide#:~:text=edit%20any%20settings.-,Groups%20admin,-Assign%20the%20groups

Hence, you're correct, A must be the answer in this case

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct. 
Group administrator can create, read, update, or delete the Microsoft 365 groups expiration policy setting. Can renew any Microsoft 365 group.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/enterprise-users/groups-lifecycle

Selected Answer: C
Need to be a Global Admin to configure the groups expiration policy.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/solutions/microsoft-365-groups-expiration-policy?view=o365-worldwide#who-can-configure-and-use-the-microsoft-365-groups-expiration-policy

Also, you need an Azure AD premium license in the tenant but not necessarily assigned. See the purple box for Notes
